title: 'Furious 7' reviews: What the critics are saying
summary:
Story highlights The film is out in theaters todayCo-star Paul Walker died during productionCritics say "Furious 7" is bittersweet and "plenty of crazy fun"(CNN) The seventh installment of the "Fast and Furious" franchise," "Furious 7" is sure to draw fans curious about how the film handles the real-life death of co-star Paul Walker.
Here's what the critics are saying:Peter Travers, Rolling Stone: " 'Furious 7' is the best F&F by far, two hours of pure pow fueled by dedication and passionate heart.
"Chris Ziegler, The Verge: "It's entirely possible, of course, that my fandom has simply blinded me to 'Furious 7's' greatness.
"Betsy Sharkey, Los Angeles Times: "The action sequences -- from hand-to-hand combat to the crash and burn of cars -- are, as we've come to expect, not grounded in reality.
But it doesn't overwhelm -- Furious 7 is respectful, even solemn, when it needs to be, but is still, thank God, plenty of crazy fun.

title: Kenya attack: Why force not enough to stop Al-Shabaab
summary:
(CNN) The terrorist group Al-Shabaab has claimed an attack on Garissa University College in eastern Kenya, in which many people have been killed and still more taken hostage.
The first attack outside Somalia was an attack in the Ugandan capital of Kampala in 2010.
Attacking a university in northern Kenya and separating Christian from Muslim students epitomizes the way Al-Shabaab advances itself by exploiting religious, tribal and nationalist identities.
Somalia-based Al-Shabaab has been behind a string of recent attacks in Kenya, the most well-known of them being the massacre at the Westgate Shopping Centre in Nairobi in 2013.
JUST WATCHED Kenya eyewitness reveals how attack unfolded Replay More Videos ... MUST WATCH Kenya eyewitness reveals how attack unfolded 04:16 PLAY VIDEOThese entrenched inequalities help Al-Shabaab appeal to a wide variety of potential recruits, who may sympathize with and actively support the group for any number of reasons.

title: It's not over: Veterans waiting months for appointments
summary:
Another 400 veterans have waited up to six months, and 64 veterans had been waiting six months to a year for their appointments.
Records show on January 15, more than 1,600 veterans who were new patients were waiting 60 to 90 days for appointments.
It is particularly significant as the Greater Los Angeles Veterans Medical Center is the nation's largest VA health care system, caring for hundreds of thousands of U.S. veterans.
Even new patients seeking care at the Los Angeles VA for the first time can wait months to see a doctor there.
The delays in appointments are even taking place at Los Angeles clinics for mental health, where documents show more than 300 veterans have been waiting more than 30, 60, even 90 days for treatment.

title: Could your plane be hacked? (Opinion)
summary:
The risk is that a hacker sitting in the back of the plane, or even one on the ground, could use the Wi-Fi connection to hack into the avionics and then remotely fly the plane.
Then he uses other vulnerabilities both to lock the pilots out of the cockpit controls and take control of the plane himself.
It sounds like the plot of some "Die Hard" reboot, but it's actually one of the possible scenarios outlined in a new Government Accountability Office report on security vulnerabilities in modern airplanes.
We have to build security into everything that is going to be connected to the Internet.
And because they'll all be networked together, a vulnerability in one device will affect the security of everything else.

title: Queen Elizabeth II: What would you buy her?
summary:
Given her well-known love of horses, it's perhaps fitting -- some might say unimaginative -- that the majority of gifts presented to Queen Elizabeth II from world leaders last year revolved her favorite four-legged animals.
Will the young prince also inherit a love of horse racing passed down through the centuries?
Peculiar presentsAmong the more peculiar gifts given to the Queen was a miniature seven-inch throne from the "Game of Thrones" TV series, during a visit to Northern Ireland in June.
So what would one buy for the horse racing-mad monarch, that hasn't been bought before?
"At that price, it's a gift fit for a Queen.

title: Opinion: Big ideas for an era of small-ball politics
summary:
Two big ideas strike at the heart of who we are as a nation and what we offer our citizens.
Big ideas about how to organize our government and ourselves, how to structure our economy, how to reform our educational system and our working conditions.
Other big ideas worth considering include a smart plan to fix our political system: The answer for elections dominated by big donors is to make everyone a political donor.
"Big ideas for a new America expand well beyond government policy, however.
If we start with ideas -- not just speeches, but real ideas -- the politics will follow.

title: Best and worst foods to eat when sick
summary:
Best foods: Slayton recommends "golden milk," which includes turmeric, a spice known for its anti-inflammatory properties.
Best foods: Water and other fluids are your best bet.
Worst foods: Spicy foods can cause an immediate runny nose (which then turns into congestion), as may alcohol.
Worst foods: Dairy can thicken phlegm and worsen congestion, with the exception of yogurt, which contains probiotics, says Dr. Arthur.
"Best foods: Omega-3 containing foods such as fatty fish (salmon, sardines) and walnut and flax seed oils, as well as foods high in protein are all important for skin health, says Dr. Arthur.

Story highlights Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force takes receipt of newly-commissioned helicopter carrierThe ship, named the Izumo, is the largest Japanese military ship since the Second World WarCritics in neighboring countries say the ship could contravene Japan's pacifist constitution(CNN) Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force (MSDF) has taken delivery of the Izumo, the largest Japanese military vessel to see service since World War II.
Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe allowed for a reinterpreting of Japan's constitution, paving the way for more active military engagement overseas.
The warship was unveiled at a ceremony at the Yokusuka naval base near Yokohama, also home to the U.S Navy's Seventh Fleet.
"It would cost five times Japan's current defense spending for the SDF to have an independent operational capability.

title: Why your commute is bad for you
summary:
Here are five ways your car, train, or bus ride to the office can affect your wellbeing, plus what to do about it.
While back pain is one of the most common health complaints, only one in four people who commute 10 minutes or less reported pain in the same poll.
But making an effort to sit up straight—with a lumbar support behind your lower back, and your head evenly over your shoulders—can help you reverse bad habits.
)"One way to combat this could be for employers to allow people to commute at different times of the day, so they're not spending so much time in traffic," Hoehner adds.

Talia shadowed our team twice during her other CNN internships and we’re happy to finally have her working alongside us this summer.

title: How obsidian Stone-Age knives still cut it in surgery
summary:
Cutting edgeObsidian -- a type of volcanic glass -- can produce cutting edges many times finer than even the best steel scalpels.
"For studies where trace metals from ordinary scalpel blades cannot be tolerated, these very special obsidian scalpels may provide the answer," the company says.
Dr. Lee Green, professor and chair of the Department of Family Medicine at the University of Alberta, says he routinely uses obsidian blades.
Using cultured-skin burn dressing, a substance composed of skin cells, he made an incision with a modern scalpel and a parallel incision with an obsidian scalpel.
At 30 angstroms -- a unit of measurement equal to one hundred millionth of a centimeter -- an obsidian scalpel can rival diamond in the fineness of its edge.

title: Hillary Clinton has a new position on same-sex marriage
summary:
READ: Hillary Clinton's gender tightropeAs a candidate in 2008, Clinton opposed same-sex marriage, supporting the idea of civil unions instead.
Now, in a markedly new position, Clinton is offering just that, calling gay marriage a right afforded by the Constitution.
She did not proclaim her personal support for same-sex marriage until 2013, after she left her diplomatic position as secretary of state.
"Hillary Clinton supports marriage equality and hopes the Supreme Court will come down on the side of same-sex couples being guaranteed that constitutional right," said Adrienne Elrod, a Clinton spokeswoman, in a statement.
"The dignity of every person tells us that the right to marry is not a state right, it is a human right," O'Malley tweeted.

title: The man who spies on penguins for science
summary:
When I say I'm "tagging," I'm manually annotating penguins, chicks and eggs on photographs taken in the region.
I've become one of the nearly million citizen scientists working to help penguins in the Antarctic region through data analysis on hosted through Zooniverse, a crowdsourcing science platform.
(CNN) Today I'm tagging penguins in Antarctica.
(Now it's) like having a really good, dedicated biologist who doesn't eat or sleep -- just dedicated to monitoring penguins 24/7.
TH: We put timelapse cameras all around Antarctica and sub-Antarctic -- South Georgia, the South Sandwich Islands, South Shetlands -- all along the Antarctic peninsula.

summary:

Such things work great—on anything that isn't approaching the speed of sound.
It's not talking dollar figures yet, but anything that cuts fuel use without cutting Wi-Fi is bound to interest airlines.

title: Meet the stars of New York's cat cafe
summary:
He is one of the stars of New York City's first cat cafe, Meow Parlour, which opened on Monday to much fanfare and a full reservation book.
But being billed as a novelty cat cafe merely scratches the surface, say cafe founders Christina Ha and Emilie Legrand.
There is a separate storefront around the corner, the Meow Parlour Patisserie, where customers can purchase baked goods and beverages to bring into the cafe.
"I think we'll feel really like we've made it when we get our first cat adopted," Ha said.
For a cat to be placed in the cafe, it has to have a clean bill of health, get along with other cats and be nonaggressive.

title: Gap between richest universities and the rest got wider
summary:
The wealth gap between the nation's 40 richest colleges and universities and the rest is getting wider.
But half of the wealthiest schools were state schools, led by the universities of Texas, California and Michigan.
Eighteen of the wealthiest schools have Aaa credit ratings -- that's a rare achievement for any businesses or government.
Harvard is the richest school with $42.8 billion assets, followed by the University of Texas at $36.7 billion.
The richest schools had average investment returns of 50% between 2009 and 2014.

title: Rolling Stone still hasn't learned its lesson (Opinion)
summary:
"What would Rolling Stone in its heyday write about an institution that screwed up unbelievably, damaged people's lives, but punished no one?
Publisher Jann Wenner has apparently decided not to fire, demote or discipline anybody at Rolling Stone, provoking expressions of disbelief among seasoned journalists.
Unfortunately, the early word from Rolling Stone is that they've absorbed none of these lessons.
"The problem could be, says Grueskin, that Rolling Stone had too many chefs in the kitchen, instead of "a single, talented editor with an intact set of vertebrae.
"Rolling Stone outsources its investigation to Columbia and proceeds to do nothing in terms of individual accountability afterward?

title: Dr. Sanjay Gupta: Vaccines are a matter of fact
summary:
Story highlights Sanjay Gupta notes that vaccines have prevented 6 million deaths every year worldwideHe says facts should matter, and science should winDr. Sanjay Gupta, a practicing neurosurgeon, is the multiple Emmy-award winning chief medical correspondent for CNN.
At the heart of the vaccine argument is the awesome challenge of trying to prove a negative.
It's not just because I love my kids that I vaccinated them -- it's because I love your kids as well.
The benefit of vaccines is not a matter of opinion.
Studies, including a meta analysis of 1.2 million children this past December, show no link between vaccines and autism.
